definition: to interpret the divinatory trigrams
divinatory diagram/one of the eight divinatory trigrams of the Book of Changes 易經|易经[Yi4 jing1]/one of the sixty-four divinatory hexagrams of the Book of Changes 易經|易经[Yi4 jing1]
old variant of 辭|辞[ci2]
to resign/to dismiss/to decline/to take leave/ballad (archaic poetic genre)/variant of 詞|词[ci2]
to interpret the divinatory trigrams
interpretation of the divinatory trigrams
to foretell the future using the trigrams of the Book of Changes 易經|易经
the 64 hexagrams of the Book of Changes (I Ching or Yi Jing) 易經|易经
The Book of Changes ("I Ching")
the solid and broken lines of the eight trigrams 八卦[ba1 gua4], e.g. ☶
divinatory diagram/one of the eight divinatory trigrams of the Book of Changes 易經|易经[Yi4 jing1]/one of the sixty-four divinatory hexagrams of the Book of Changes 易經|易经[Yi4 jing1]

good and bad luck (in astrology)
divination
oracle inscriptions of the Shang Dynasty (16th-11th century BC) on tortoiseshells or animal bones
to predict by divining/to look into the future
another name for Book of Changes (I Ching) 易經|易经[Yi4 jing1]
the Book of Dao by Laozi or Lao-Tze, the sacred text of Daoism
the ten Heavenly Stems 甲[jia3], 乙[yi3], 丙[bing3], 丁[ding1], 戊[wu4], 己[ji3], 庚[geng1], 辛[xin1], 壬[ren2], 癸[gui3] (used cyclically in the calendar and as ordinal number like Roman I, II, III)
to obey/one of the Eight Trigrams 八卦[ba1 gua4], symbolizing wood and wind/☴/ancient Chinese compass point: 135° (southeast)
